passage_text: An orchiectomy (spelled orchidectomy in British English), is the medical term for the surgical procedure to remove one or more of the testicles. A bilateral orchiectomy is the removal of both testicles and is commonly referred to as castration. An orchiectomy doesn't remove the penis, which would be a penectomy. The most common reason for an orchiectomy is as a treatment for testicular cancer. If only one testicle is found to be cancerous then only that one is removed. Even if both testicles are removed, male sexual function can be restored and maintained through the use of testosterone injections or patches.

Orchiectomy, also known as Orchidectomy or Castration is a surgical procedure to remove one or both testicles in men. Testicles are sex organs in the males that produce sperms and testosterone (a hormone). Orchiectomy will make you sterile (infertile) and may reduce your sex drive due to loss of testosterone.
